ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write a compelling lab report, how to conduct fieldwork (especially how to design experiments using pitfall traps!), and about the current status of urban ecological systems.
I learned more about forest dynamics, urban ecology, and agroecology. I also learned some field skills and techniques for forest/tree studies and how to better identify trees.
Practical field research skills, along with lab report writing and modes of scientific inquiry.

I greatly improved my knowledge of trees and the complexity of ecosystem management. This course offers a great opportunity to gain hands-on field skills and learn how to run efficient forest-based field studies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed this course. One suggestion is to standardize the format of Tuesday discussions so that students know what to pay the most attention to in readings.

I think the field portion of this course is extremely rich. Sometimes the readings felt dense and somewhat random or unrelated to class. The Tuesday class slots felt best used when we got to do group work to discuss the readings. The Thursday field time was always fun and enriching! 
I also found the field lab write-ups to be slightly challenging because they were so open ended, yet we still had to conform to the lab report format. Perhaps if there was a secondary option for these reports that could be more research based but less focused on the experimental part, or one that was more experiment/statistics based...
This class does a fantastic job of tying hands-on field research with the academic literature, and class and personal research projects.

The lab reports for this class are very interesting and important for learning how to write scientific papers. However, many students did not have experience writing this style of paper before the class. Having more structured writing time for the first lab report (i.e. having students submit their introduction and/or questions before the full paper is due) would be helpful as students work through these reports.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The course is very engaging, interactive, and informative. It provides insight into the life of a research scientist and touches upon some really interesting topics.

Yes I would recommend this class because the field portion was very fun but I do think it is important that you specifically want to learn more about the three units (agroecology, forested landscapes, and urban ecology) because other than mentioning climate change, the course doesn't really go into any other environmental topics.

Absolutely! This class is a fantastic way to engage with the natural environment in CT. This is a chance to be both hands-on in the field, and to practice writing lab reports and formualting interesting scientific questions in a natural science context. The small class size and wonderful professor also creates a wonderful class community throughout the semester.
Yes, this is a great course for any student interested in persuing field science.
